text: If you think about currencies, a currency doesn't have a value unless it's related to another currency. So euro doesn't have a value unless it's quoted in dollar terms. Or sterling doesn't have a value unless it's quoted in yen terms. So when you think about relative performance between two currency pairs, you really need to have a third currency, which is a common currency. Whenever you think about options and vol, you need to think about the triangle relationship. And then if you think about how we measure realized volatility, whether one currency outperforms another, we can basically think about many correlation triangles, whereas every correlation has three vols and three subset of correlations. So if we take G10 effects, we have 10 currencies in G10 that makes 45 currency pairs. So it's 10 times 9 divided by 2. Obviously, not every single currency pair in G10. But if you look at the G10 effects, out of those 45 is tradable in the market. So some currency pairs like, say, Aussie versus Swedish Krone, it would not be super liquid. And most of the dealers are not going to quote you that option. But assuming that there is a liquid market to all those currency pairs, you basically have 360 correlation triangles. So you are in a multidimensional correlation world. So I think that it's very difficult for dealers to make a decision. And I think that dealers can't maintain those 360 correlation triangles aligned at any given point in time. There are so many opportunities there. But obviously, if something has a very high correlation, so it's very close to 1, no one would quote you correlation at 1. Because dealers understand that obviously everybody wants a short correlation at 1 and by correlation at minus 1. So obviously, there will be some skewed quote to that. But if you think about it, dealers can't maintain those correlation triangles in line. So what they do usually, they usually widen prices on stuff that are illiquid. And on some stuff, they will not quote you. So mostly, if you trade correlation, you never want to go and do the traditional correlation trade, which is trading three vanilla trades or three bar swaps because it's too expensive. So as a correlation trader, what you always want to do, you want to trade some relative value between two currency pairs. And basically, what you want to own some idiosyncratic risk. Because market risk is very important. If you have a high risk, you can edge away and diversify away. But idiosyncratic risk is what you want to own. Whereas something that has a high beta risk, you want to short if it has a low idiosyncratic risk.
